Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Enabling Economic Policies in Software-Defined Internet Exchange Points

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Internet routing---particularly inter-domain routing---suffers from a long list of well-known problems that makes it difficult to innovate new types of end-to-end services and applications. Routing decisions are made locally by routers based on policies that users and their applications have little control over, resulting in routing decisions that are not optimized for users or their applications. Moreover, the "money flow," from customers through a sequence of providers that handle their packets, is determined by business relationships (service-level agreements (SLAs)) among providers---which change very slowly. One consequence is that it is virtually impossible in today's Internet to offer an end-to-end service with any real predictability of quality, let alone a guarantee. Moreover, concerns about network providers discriminating against some providers? content (see the net neutrality debate) add another dimension of complexity.

Software-Defined Networking (SDN) is an emerging networking paradigm in which data traffic is routed at the granularity of individual flows by a programmable controller. The ability to route flows at a finer granularity than destination prefixes, and the potential for various stakeholders to express and enforce routing policies for their traffic have made SDN appealing also for inter-domain routing. At the same time, an increasing number of inter-provider connections are being realized at Internet Exchange Points (IXPs). In this context, Software-Defined Internet Exchange Points (SDX) have been proposed as a way for multiple providers to collectively control the routing decisions at Internet Exchange Points (IXPs). Most SDX research has focused on the problems associated with composed and possibly conflicting policies specified by providers or with scalability issues implementing flow-level policies at major IXPs with large numbers of flow.

Intellectual Merit: While SDXs hold great potential, they also exhibit considerable challenges: SDXs offer mechanisms to enforce (certain types of) policies, but they do not define policies. The frameworks needed to define policies are an open area of research. Policies are typically derived from economic relationships established between providers, or between providers and their customers. Moreover, access to, and use of, resources at an SDX itself (e.g., network capacity, processing, and storage) requires that an economic relationship be established between a provider and the SDX. In other words, SDXs act as marketplaces, marketing their resources to providers (e.g., the right to use link bandwidth, processing cycles, and storage), and SDXs provide a way for providers to market their (transit) services to other providers on behalf of their customers. Current SDX designs do not consider these economic relationships and thus omit a critical aspect of Internet operation. This project includes fundamental research aimed at the design of controllers for Software-Defined Internet Exchange Points that can be programmed to implement end-to-end (i.e., inter-domain) routing policies that are tied to explicit economic relationships between network entities.

Broader Impacts: The results from this research have the potential for a transformative impact on how inter-domain routing---which is at the core of economic interactions between network providers in the Internet---is implemented and used to provide novel services in networks. The interdisciplinary nature of this work---crossing the boundaries of engineering and economics---presents particular challenges in developing solutions that are technically sound and can be adopted in practice. The work involves an education component. Results from our work will be disseminated in the form of open-source toolsets and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored how emerging network technologies can be used in innovative ways to enable faster and finer-grained economic agreements between network service providers. Network providers connect with each other at exchange points so that traffic from one provider can be passed to another provider on its way to the destination. Software-Defined Networking has enabled such exchange points to be configured dynamically. In our work, we have studied mechanisms that use software-defined technology in the exchange point so that traffic exchanged can be enabled based on short-term economic agreements that can be determined between adjacent network providers. The interdisciplinary nature of this project?crossing the boundaries of engineering and economics?led to solutions that are technically sound and could be adopted in practice.

In this project, we designed the operation of such a system to explore the necessary interactions. We clarified the interfaces of a software-defined exchange point that combine routing and economics, as well as the relationship to conventional routing protocols. We presented work that argues that such a system can enhance interdomain transport and provide lower latency connection between end-points that are connected to different provider networks.

The foundational building block of our system is called a Coin-Operated SDX controller, or simply Coin-Op SDX. The Coin-Op SDX provides a simple and well-defined interface by which providers can collectively control the behavior of the exchange point switching fabric. As the Coin-Op SDX name implies, providers include payment (i.e., a ?coin?) to use the exchange point, thereby bringing economics into the picture. Higher-level services (e.g., broker services) can combine these building block services to create new end-to-end transit services not possible in today?s Internet.

Our work has spanned the design and operation of this coin-op SDX, possible implementation with existing Software-Defined Networking technologies, security considerations to ensure robustness against attacks, and economic models to ensure stable operation. We have also studied how to implement access control, rule conflicts, and the expiration of rules during the dynamic operation of the system. 

The result of this work may enable new types of network services that cannot easily be implemented in today?s network, for example, due to the delay that is incurred by traversing a distant peering point. An explosion in the number of connected devices?vehicles, home appliances, municipal infrastructure, industrial machinery, etc.?is associated with the so-called ?Internet of Things.? At the same time, more and more consumer computation is associated with mobile applications. These trends are driving interest in edge (or ?fog?) computing, in which compute and storage resources reside in smaller, distributed data center facilities located closer to the consumer. A primary motivation for this architecture is a need for lower latency than can be achieved when the back-end is in a remote datacenter, due to speed-of-light limitations. This may present a problem if the data center and the consumer do not connect to the same service provider network, and the two providers do not interconnect nearby, but traffic has to traverse a distant peering point. In contrast, our exchange point could act as a ?peering point in a box? that can directly connect provider networks locally. The ability to establish an economic relationship on the spot without requiring the setup of complex service-level agreements can enable new paths that connect provider networks locally, thus solving the problem of long paths between local nodes that use different providers

Beyond the broad applicability of our research results to the design of network exchange points, this project has offered extensive graduate student training. Results from our work have been disseminated in the form publications in peer-reviewed conferences and journals.
